Award.AwardTitle: International Travel Support during 2015 for U.S.-Japan Research Collaboration on the Seismic Design and Testing of Mid-Rise Reinforced Concrete Buildings

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support travel to Japan during August and December 2015 for four U.S. researchers to meet with Japanese collaborators to develop a seismic testing program for two full-scale, ten-story reinforced concrete building models. The building models will be tested for seismic performance on the E-Defense shake table operated by Japan's National Research Institute for Earth Science and Disaster Prevention (NIED). The cost for these shake table tests will be supported by a NIED research project. By working with Japanese researchers, the U.S. researchers will contribute to the design and testing of the structures, and will gain access to the test data to use in subsequent research analyses. The data will serve the U.S. national need of improving the resilience of buildings and communities against future earthquakes. The U.S. participants will be selected to best represent the research subject, as well as to promote participation from underrepresented groups. This award is part of the National Earthquake Hazards Reduction Program.

This collaboration will be the second phase of a two-phase U.S.-Japan research collaboration on the seismic performance of reinforced concrete buildings tested on the E-Defense shake table. In 2009-2010, researchers from Japan and the U.S. completed the first phase, which included the design, planning, seismic testing on the E-Defense shake table, and post-test analyses of two four-story buildings, one of conventional reinforced concrete and another of post-tensioned concrete. The second phase of this collaboration will involve the seismic design and testing on the E-Defense shake table of two full-scale, ten-story reinforced concrete buildings. The first test is planned for December 2015. In preparation for the December testing, a team of four U.S. researchers will travel to Japan during August and December 2015 to meet with Japanese collaborators. In these joint meetings with Japanese collaborators, the U.S. team will participate in design and testing of the structures so as to maximize the lessons learned for both Japan and the U.S. The test structures will have many features in common with U.S. reinforced concrete buildings, including moment frames and rectangular shear walls designed to withstand effects associated with inelastic response of buildings subjected to strong earthquakes that drive the buildings to near collapse. Seismic isolation will also be considered. The U.S. participants will aim to gather data that can serve as the basis for future research by U.S. investigators, including research on computational models to simulate response of buildings to strong earthquake shaking.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Science Foundation (NSF) in the United States and the National Research Institute for Earth Science and Disaster Prevention (NIED) in Japan have promoted various research on seismic performance of buildings and other structures at E-Defense (Full-scale Three-dimensional Earthquake Testing Facility). These studies have been especially productive when they involved collaboration in test planning, test conduct, and data sharing for post-test analyses. 

In 2009-2010, researchers in the U.S and Japan undertook Phase 1 of a two-phase US-Japan Collaboration on Reinforced Concrete (RC) Buildings Utilizing E-Defense, with primary funding by NIED Research Project. With support from the U.S. National Science Foundation, U.S. researchers participated in test design, planning, conduct, and post-test analyses of two four-story buildings: a conventional RC building and a post-tensioned concrete building.   

The current project supported participation of US researchers in Phase 2 of the US-Japan Collaboration on RC Buildings Utilizing E-Defense. In this phase, two full-scale, 10-story reinforced concrete buildings are planned for design, construction, and testing on the E-Defense facility. The tests on the first structure took place in November and December 2015. The tests explored global and local behaviors under a sliding base condition (using a simple and inexpensive sliding mechanism) and a more conventional fixed base condition. In the fixed base condition, the structure was tested to near collapse. Six U.S. researchers travelled to Japan for one pre-test meeting and for one meeting during and immediately following the tests. During these meetings, the Japan side shared complete details of the construction and testing of the first structure. The Japan side has not shared any digital data from the test program.

The Japan side also invited the U.S. participants to continue collaboration on the design, testing, and analysis of the second structure of this test phase. As of the time of this writing, those tests have yet to take place.  

The project was valuable because it extended collaboration activities between US and Japanese researchers in the important subject of earthquake-resistant building design. Through participation in the test planning, the US researchers also learned valuable information about seismic performance of reinforced concrete buildings, which will influence future research and building standards development. 

The broader impacts of the research include: (1) Maintaining the tradition of strong US-Japan research on RC buildings; (2) Promoting frameworks for productive future US-Japan collaboration on high-performance RC buildings; (3) Fostering mechanisms for data exchange on E-Defense and NHERI projects, and (4) Enabling subsequent NHERI projects based on the large-scale E-Defense tests.
